title: Martin O'Connor (footballer)
text:
Martin John O'Connor (born 10 December 1967) is a <a href="association%20football">football</a> coach and former professional player. Born in England, he represented the <a href="Cayman%20Islands%20national%20football%20team">Cayman Islands</a> at international level.
Club career.
O'Connor was a late entrant to senior football. He joined <a href="Southern%20Football%20League">Southern League Premier Division</a> club <a href="Bromsgrove%20Rovers%20F.C.">Bromsgrove Rovers</a> in his early 20s, and played his part in their winning the <a href="1991%E2%80%9392%20Southern%20Football%20League">1991–92 title</a>. He signed for <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a> for a £25,000 fee ahead of the <a href="1992%E2%80%9393%20FA%20Premier%20League">inaugural Premier League season</a>, but never appeared in that league. Instead, he made his <a href="English%20Football%20League">Football League</a> debut at the age of 25 during the first of three spells at <a href="Walsall%20F.C.">Walsall</a>, joining on loan in March 1993 before signing permanently the following year. He played a key role in the Saddlers winning promotion to <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Division Two</a> in <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20Football%20League%23Third%20Division">1994–95</a>.
He then joined <a href="Peterborough%20United%20F.C.">Peterborough United</a>, followed by <a href="Birmingham%20City%20F.C.">Birmingham City</a>, whom O'Connor represented in the <a href="2001%20Football%20League%20Cup%20Final">2001 Football League Cup Final</a> against <a href="Liverpool%20F.C.">Liverpool</a>, which Birmingham lost in a <a href="Penalty%20shoot-out%20%28association%20football%29">penalty shootout</a>.
O'Connor re-joined Walsall in 2002, but his contract was not renewed at the end of the 2002–03 season. He then signed for <a href="Shrewsbury%20Town%20F.C.">Shrewsbury Town</a> in July 2003, before ending his playing career with <a href="Kidderminster%20Harriers%20F.C.">Kidderminster Harriers</a>.
He was <a href="player-manager">player-manager</a> of <a href="Halesowen%20Town%20F.C.">Halesowen Town</a> from November 2006 until October 2007. On 20 January 2009, he was named assistant manager to <a href="Chris%20Hutchings">Chris Hutchings</a> at <a href="Walsall%20F.C.">Walsall</a>, but the pair were sacked on 3 January 2011 after a series of poor results left Walsall bottom of <a href="Football%20League%20One">Football League One</a>.
After <a href="Dean%20Keates">Dean Keates</a> was sacked as Walsall manager in April 2019 with the team in the relegation places, O'Connor was appointed for the remaining five matches of <a href="2018%E2%80%9319%20Walsall%20F.C.%20season">the season</a>. Despite overseeing a stunning 3–0 victory against <a href="Peterborough%20United">Peterborough United</a> on 27 April 2019 taking the fight for survival to the last game of the season, O'Connor ultimately could not stop the Saddlers' relegation to <a href="League%20Two">League Two</a>. O'Connor was succeeded as Walsall manager by <a href="Darrell%20Clarke">Darrell Clarke</a> who signed a three-year contract on 10 May 2019.
International career.
O'Connor was called up to the <a href="Cayman%20Islands%20national%20football%20team">Cayman Islands national football team</a> in 2000; his father was born in that country. He played twice before <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> ruled that neither he nor many others who had been invited were eligible. The Cayman Islands had been attempting to exploit their status as a <a href="British%20Overseas%20Territory">British Overseas Territory</a> by picking British passport holders who would not ordinarily be eligible to play for them.
Honours.
Walsall
